data.text: Contents
Introduction
The purpose of the policy is:
To describe the Trust's approach to the management of stress
To define the key responsibilities in relation to the management of stress
To ensure that systems are in place to identify stress and also to ensure that all employees are fully supported

The Trust is committed to promoting a good, supportive climate and healthy working culture, where stress is not seen as a personal weakness, and where employees experiencing stress or mental health problems can access appropriate support.
The Trust is also committed to supporting employees in achieving a healthy work-
life balance and to supporting employees who have experienced traumatic or distressing event.

The Trust recognises that the environment within the NHS is pressurised and challenging. The Trust is committed to caring for the health and safety of all its employees physically and psychologically.
Work-related stress is a major cause of occupational ill-health. It is well documented by the Health and Safety Executive and NHS Employers that work-related stress
has adverse effects for organisational efficiency in terms of:
Employee's commitment to work
Performance
Retention and intention to leave
Attendance
Patient care

Managing stress effectively will help organisations, their employees and their representatives minimise the impact of work-related stress. The Trust is committed to meeting its legal obligations and staff wellbeing in regards to the management of stress, and this includes:
Management of Health and Safety at work Regulations  These regulations require the Trust to assess the risk of stress-related ill health arising from work activities
Health and Safety at Work Act, 1974. This act imposes duties on the Trust to take measure to control that risk.
Scope
This policy applies to all employees working for the Trust including bank, locum, visiting healthcare workers and volunteers.
Definitions

table_items.text: The definition of stress that the Trust has adopted is that used by the Health and Safety Executive (HSE):”Stress is the adverse reaction people have to excessive pressure or other types of demand placed on them.”

The common term for these excessive pressures or demands is ‘stressors' and a person's reaction to a stressor is termed a “stress response”. However there is a clear difference between stress and pressure. Stressors can be detrimental to health, pressure, if managed correctly, can be positive, challenging and motivating in the workplace.
Risk Assessment is the process used to evaluate the hazard and risk to determine whether precautions are adequate or if more should be done.
Health and Safety Executive Management Standards

The Trust will use the Health and Safety Executives Management Standards for Work Related Stress (MSWRS) to assist in the reduction of workplace stress. The HSE MSWRS identify the following six key potential stressors at work that, if properly managed proactively, can help to reduce work- related stress: Demands – issues such as workload, work patterns and the work environment Control – how much say the person has in the way they do their work Support – The encouragement, sponsorship and resources provided by the organisation, line management and colleagues Relationships – Promoting positive working to avoid conflict and dealing with unacceptable behaviour Role – Whether people understand their role within the organisation and whether the organisation ensures that they do not have conflicting roles Change – How organizational change (large or small) is managed and communicated in the organisation

data.text: Role and responsibilities within the Trust
The Health and Safety Management Group

The Health and Safety Group Committee meets and reports on a quarterly basis and is responsible for reviewing and receiving reports on, and monitoring compliance in relation to work related stress within the Trust. The group are also responsible for monitoring compliance with annual departmental stress risk assessments.
Role and Responsibilities of Individuals within the Trust: Chief Executive

The Chief Executive as the Accounting Officer has overall responsibility for the quality and safety of services provided by the Trust. The CEO is responsible for ensuring that the infrastructure required to support the delivery and implementation of this document is available. The CEO will delegate the full implementation of this policy to the relevant Executive Director for People and Organisational Development.
Director of Workforce

The Director of Workforce along with other Senior Management will ensure, as far as reasonably practicable, the health and wellbeing of staff is maintained whilst at work. This duty includes taking reasonable steps to ensure that staff do not experience excessive pressure or stress as a result of work. Director of workforce will ensure, as far as reasonably practicable:
That robust systems are in place to maintain a safe place of work, safe systems of work and a safe and healthy working environment
There is provision of information and training to enhance the health, safety and wellbeing of employees whilst at work
Awareness and understanding of hazards that undermine wellbeing is promoted
To monitor and review the effectiveness of the Wellbeing policy in improving the enthusiasm, commitment and motivation of its employees

The Director of Workforce Will enable the Trust to promote the continued wellbeing of its employees by identifying opportunities for improving physical, psychological and social functioning, while at the same time identifying and controlling the hazards that reduce wellbeing at work.

The Director of Workforce will take the lead on the responsibility for increasing staff' awareness of factors that will increase staff health and wellbeing. Development of skills in recognising when staff or a colleague is experiencing personal or work- related difficulties, and provide information on how to obtain appropriate support or make referrals for counselling.
Line managers

Appendix 1 Supporting Employees Experience of Stress at Work provides guidance for managers and allows managers to promote a management style that encourages participation, delegation, constructive feedback, mentoring and coaching
Should be able to motivate employees and provide them with the training and support they need to develop their performance and job satisfaction.
Should have an understanding of how management style and practices can help to promote the mental wellbeing of employees and keep their stress to a minimum.
Should know when it is necessary to refer an employee to occupational health.
Should ensure that a departmental/divisional risk assessment is completed, addressed and, control measures implemented to any areas identified by the risk assessment.

If a manager notices a member of their team having difficulties in undertaking their work, the manager has a responsibility to discuss the difficulties and to give help and support on deciding an appropriate course of action. Staff should not suffer any detrimental effects or stigmatised for disclosing any health and wellbeing issues.

An individual risk assessment must be undertaken. The manager must ensure that staff are referred to occupational health department ,if the impact of difficulties is undermining staff physical, psychological or social wellbeing,
Employee responsibility
Employees must be involved in the risk management process and take an active role in any recommendations.

The balance of responsibility for employee wellbeing is not one sided. Whilst the employer has responsibility for the health and welfare of the workforce, the Law also places a duty on employees to take reasonable care of their own health and safety. These responsibilities can be discussed with line managers in the wellbeing conversations and one to one meetings

Employees can generate their own pressures and demands, for example employees may have unreasonable expectations of what that they can achieve and set themselves unrealistic targets, or they may resist help even when it has been offered to them. This lack of “personal caring” (i.e. caring for yourself) can create increasing individual stressors
Employees must inform their line manager of any problems that they may be experiencing which affects their health and wellbeing at work.

For Employees to be supported, it is in their interest to allow themselves access to interventions to assist them in their coping skills, including education and training and the services offered by occupational health, including counselling.
Human Resources
Ensure the promotion of mental wellbeing should be integrated into all policies and practices concerned with managing people, including those related to employment rights and working conditions.
Ensure that processes for job design, selection, recruitment, training, development and appraisal promote mental wellbeing and reduce the potential for stigma and discrimination.
They offer guidance and support to managers on implementing their responsibilities under this policy and its relationship with other policies.
Assist in monitoring and evaluating the effectiveness of this policy.

Give guidance and support to managers and employees on where they can access support for their staff or themselves if they appear to be experiencing work related pressure or stress. They will direct them to either seek advice from their GP or from the occupational health department.
Occupational Health and Wellbeing Department
Provide specialist advice to managers and employees on health and wellbeing and recognising and tackling excessive work pressure.

Assist in training and supporting managers in implementing risk assessments. This includes a module within the managers training that incorporates stress awareness training and how to support employees

Provide support and assistance to individuals who are experiencing pressure which is affecting their physical, psychological or social wellbeing. Employees should be encouraged to ask their line manager to refer them to the Occupational Health and Wellbeing Department via the management referral system. Employees can contact occupational health and wellbeing team for advice either through the MSEhealthyMe@nhs.net or mse.occhealth@nhs.net where they will be signposted to appropriate pathway or necessary referral
Monitor the effectiveness of this policy as described in the Monitoring and Audit section of this policy.
The risk assessment process

The risk assessment process is a familiar concept within the Trust and is embedded as part of our risk management culture (i.e. accident/incident investigation, moving and handling assessments, display screen equipment etc).
Risk assessing for work related stress should be regarded as no different to any other risk in the workplace, albeit the factors are slightly more complicated than for physical hazards.
The purpose of carrying out a risk assessment is to identify if existing control measures preventing harm are sufficient, or if more should be done.

The HSE have issued guidelines to assist in the identification and tackling of work related stress. They have also identified a list of management standards which will help you through the risk assessment process. These guidelines have been incorporated in this policy.
Consultation

It is important that line managers consult and inform their team, this includes consulting with Trade Union Representatives and Safety Representatives to ensure that they are aware of timely communication and what the managers are trying to achieve. Managers should explain what you are going to be doing, how you will be going about it and what involvement you expect from the team. You will need to provide full feedback on the outcome and results.
Managers guide for risk assessment process
The first step in assessing the risk is to start by identifying hazards. The methods described below are for guidance only, it is suggested that a combination of both approaches is used.
Looking at existing data
As an organisation the Trust already collects information that can be used to obtain a broad indication of the health and well-being of our employees. For example:

Sickness absence data - have a look at your departments/divisional sickness absence data. How does it compare with the Trust average? How does it compare to this time last year? Is it increasing? Check the reasons given for absence; is there an underlying trend or cause? Is depression or work-related stress being given as a reason?
Employee turnover – look at recruitment and retention rates. Do you have a high turnover; if so examine the reasons why.
Productivity data, i.e. local or national targets –If targets are being missed or productivity is lower than expected, explore the reasons for this by consulting with your staff
Work patterns - peaks and troughs in activity or certain types of activity e.g. distressing or traumatic events, or even periods of intensive but repetitive tasks can cause problems.
Surveys and questionnaires
Building a picture of your departments stress risk factors can be undertaken easily:
Informal talks/walks through your department
Appraisal process - offers an opportunity for a one-to-one discussion about work and how individuals are coping
Return to work interviews - will show whether an employee is identifying a work- related problem, or is perhaps suffering stress due to outside factors

Structured individual interviews and focus groups - these can be run as part of a department meeting, they should however cover a broad spectrum of employees. Useful questions and tips for running a focus group can be found in appendix 5
The completed questionnaires will be collated by the Occupational Health Department who will be able to provide you with the results
Staff Satisfaction Surveys - information and data can be drawn from the Staff Satisfaction survey. This will help you form a clear picture of your staff's health and well-being at work
Hazards Identified

When you have gathered all the information and further consulted with your team, you will have a clearer picture of the factors which are or have the potential to exacerbate work related stress. You will understand which team members are likely to be more affected and what particular aspect of their work is a potential trigger.
You will need to consider:

What action is already being taken and what processes and policies are already in place to tackle some of the issues i.e. regular team meetings held, flexible working contracts in place, regular supervision and feedback. A list of associated documents can be found at the beginning of this policy
Is it enough? What more needs to be done?
Risk considered

The risk assessment will allow line manager to record the findings of the identified risks in their work areas and the impact this will have on their employees. The findings will formulate the action plan to identify the risk level and the control measures that are required to be implemented to significantly reduce any risks (Appendix 3).
Review
The risk assessment process will need to be reviewed at least every year or sooner if there are significant changes in the department/division
Individual stress risk assessment

An  individual  risk  assessment  will  be  indicated  when  an  individual  employee indicates to their manager that they are experiencing stress at work. This may arise following a referral to the Occupational Health Department or from a conversation during an appraisal, one to one or return to work interview. The individual risk assessment  will  follow  the  same  risk  factors  as  a  Divisional/Departmental  risk assessment, but it will focus on the person rather than the department. An action plan, mutually agreed between the employee and the manager will be formulated and reviewed.
Training requirements
Training and support to complete the risk assessment can be accessed through the Occupational Health and Wellbeing service or the Health and Safety Team.

People and Organisational Development provide training that can assist with well- being that are either stand-alone workshops or an integral part of accredited courses run by the department. Stress and Well-being literature will be made available on the Occupational Health and Wellbeing Department's page on the Internet and Intranet.
Monitoring and audit
Outlined below is the Trust's process of monitoring compliance with, and the effectiveness of the document's main points.

Appendix 1: Supporting employees experiencing stress at work
Introduction

The Wellbeing policy and risk assessment guidelines focus on a preventative, proactive approach to help identify and tackle work-related pressure. However, it is inevitable that some employees may experience symptoms of excessive pressure (see table of symptoms on page 5) and managers have a responsibility to ensure this is acted upon promptly.
Early reporting is the key

Employees should be encouraged to report any health problems to their manager at the earliest possibility if they feel their health problems may be caused or exacerbated by work; as the Trust can only respond to those situations we are made aware of. By the time an employee is diagnosed by their GP as suffering from a stress-related illness and is perhaps signed unfit to work, the problem may be significantly more difficult to deal with. Occupational Health will be able to guide you through the process to follow should you be concerned about a member of staff.

As a manager there are some things you need to be aware of to enable you to feel comfortable and confident in dealing with a member of staff who presents with health problems associated with excessive pressure.

Consider the fact that employees often report problems as a consequence of factors at home and work, therefore you need to develop the skills needed to deal with distressed team members and tackle identified work related needs locally or in consultation with your line manager.
Try not to be panicked by (their) emotions. Acceptance, reassurance and a calm measured response is recommended.
Make sure the individual does not feel penalised for feeling the effects of too much pressure.

Encourage the employee to manage their own wellbeing; encourage them to think about what they can do to help themselves. Make sure you provide them with information about the support on offer (ie. occupational health, counselling).
Find out from the employee what you can do to help rather than just decide a particular course of action without consultation.

If the employee thinks work is a factor, try to establish which risk factor(s) (see section 6) is associated with the problem. Look at your department stress risk assessment to check whether it needs to be reviewed and undertake an individual risk assessment in consultation with the employee.
What if your employee goes off sick?

The Attendance Management policy should be followed particularly with regard to maintaining contact with the employee whilst they are off sick. It is important to maintain contact not only to show our concern but also to monitor progress and to demonstrate our commitment to helping them achieve a successful return to work when the time is right. Managers must be sensitive to the employees needs at a potentially vulnerable time; too many phone calls may be perceived as harassment.

If an employee is sick for 28 days, this is regarded as long term sickness absence and the appropriate referral should be made to occupational health, first ensuring consultation and consent for referral has taken place.
Returning to work
It is important to consider the factors that caused the absence and if necessary address those issues before return to work is possible.
The successful return of a member of staff back to work after a period of absence is, very much depends on how effective and appropriate the rehabilitation programme is.

The return to work strategy will be guided by occupational health in consultation with the manager and employee. It may involve an initial return on a limited number of days/hours gradually building up to a full return to work. It may include temporary restrictions on particular tasks or duties that may previously have posed difficulties for the employee. In some circumstances the Disability Discrimination Act may apply and it may be appropriate to investigate permanent readjustment or redeployment to facilitate the employee returning to work.
The employee should be monitored carefully to ensure return to work is successful and to respond quickly should there be any difficulties.
Appendix 2: Top  stress busting tips
Top 10 Stress Busting Tips
1) Get active
Exercise is a great way to help manage some of the emotional intensity associated with stress. Physical activity, be it gentle walking or vigorous running, can help clear your
thoughts and provide space to deal with problems calmly.
2) Take control
Althou gh stress can feel overwhelming, there's a solution to any problem. Feeling that you have no control is a key cause of stress. Facing problems head on and taking control of
situations is a key part of finding solutions to stress.
3) Connect with others
Turning to friends, family and/or colleagues is a good way to help you see things from a
different perspective and find solutions to problems. Social activities can be great stress relievers, even if it's a virtual catch up with friends.
4) Try something new
Set yourself a goal to learn a new language, take up a new sport, do some volunteering, or start a hobby. Focusing on the challenge with help ease your stress can give you a
confidence boost.
5) Make time for yourself
We all need time to ourselves for socialising and relaxation. Try setting aside just a few nights or daytimes a week for quality ‘me time' – be it reading a chapter or two of your
favourite book or chilling out with a Netflix boxset.
Top 10 stress busting tips
6) Avoid unhealthy behaviours

Don't turn to alcohol, smoking and caffeine as coping strategies. Although it may seem to give  immediate relief from stress, in the long term these habits won't solve your problems but just make new ones.
7) Take time to help others

Evidence shows that people who get involved in their local community can boost their me ntal  resilience.  Even  if  you  don't  have  time  to  do  some  volunteering,  try  helping someone with random acts of kindness. This can be as simple as doing a coffee run for yo ur work colleagues.
8) Adopt a positive outlook
Take a moment to consider the good things in life, you could even make a list of three things that went well or that you are grateful for at the end of each day.
9) Develop your time management skills
Work   smarter, not harder. Accept that your in-tray will always be full. Prioritise your workload and focus on the key tasks in order – this can make a big difference to your stress levels.
10) Accept the things you can't fix
It isn't always possible to change a difficult situation. Try to focus on the things you can contr ol and take some positive action. Even small improvements can be empowering and
boost your sense of wellbeing

Appendix 4: Guidelines for running a focus group

Focus groups are basically ways of listening to employees and learning from them, they facilitate active participation of employees in the risk assessment process for work-related stress. They also give management an opportunity to demonstrate commitment to a participative process of managing the risks from work-related stress.
Purpose
The purpose of using focus groups as part of the risk assessment process is to allow employees to draw on their own detailed knowledge of local and contextual factors to:
Explore the sources of undue pressure in their work and to enable them to share perceptions and perspectives on underlying causes etc
Confirm or challenge the findings from the questionnaire
Prioritise the specific areas for action
Explore potential solutions and develop an action plans that help address the main issues associated with work-related stress.
Planning
It is advisable to start planning your focus group sessions as soon as you have issued the Questionnaire
Selecting the group

You may wish to include this as a topic in one of your existing team meetings or you may feel that you want to set up a separate meeting specifically for this purpose, especially if you want to give a different staff group an opportunity to be represented. The results of the questionnaire will help you decide which forum is most appropriate and which members of your team/department you want to include in the focus group.

The typical size of a focus group is six to ten participants either from different pay bands ( for eg. HCA's and Nurses) where appropriate or staff ( eg: HCA or Nurses) from the same group.. This range gives scope for a large enough range of different viewpoints and opinions, while enabling all participants to make contributions without having to compete for ‘air time'.
Facilitating
As the manger you would be expected to facilitate the meeting, assistance from your Occupational Health Adviser or Personnel Adviser would be available if you feel it is necessary.
As facilitator you would be responsible for:
Setting the scene, explaining the purpose of the focus group
Introducing participants to the topics for discussion
Managing the process (timing etc)
Encouraging participation from all the group members
Controlling the flow of the discussion;
Ensuring that all the key issues are addressed
Agreeing and recording outcomes.
Planning the questions
The focus group should be planned for 1½ - 2 hours. You should think about and prepare your questions/topics beforehand and keep it to about 4 or 5 specific areas for discussion.
Questions should be open-ended and should not be leading questions. An example of an introductory question to start off discussions on the issue of work-related stress is:
“when you hear the words ‘work-related stress' what is the first thing that comes to mind”.

Open-ended questions allow the group as much freedom as possible in deciding how to reply. They do not constrain them to ‘Yes / No' answers or a limited range of options, they don't imply the type of response that is expected.
Examples of open-ended questions are: “what did you think about …the course?” “what is it like to work here?”
“how did you feel about that?”
They are sometimes phrased as requests for information or invitations to “Tell me about.”

You should then use responses to follow up with further questions to get a bit more depth. You could use the results of the questionnaire as a prompt; show the group the results and ask “how does this match up with your experience of working here?”

Use the group to assist you in finding solutions to the issues raised and between you and the focus group agree an action plan. At the end of the meeting make sure you close by ensuring that the group is aware that you will write up a summary of the meeting, including agreed actions and timescales.
